jt is the intention of the committee, if there is no evidence
that others are doing it, to draw up from the United States

The foregoing is what the executive committee have done,
are doing,and are preparing to do, in furtherance ofthe interests of this great enterprise. A few words more upon its present prospects will conclude this already too lengthy communication.
It is but a few months since the project of a railroad from
New Orleans to Opelousas was first heard of. When suggested the scheme was generally scouted as visionary, or
absurd. There were supposed to be natural obstacles which
would render its construction quite impossible. Even its utility was doubted : many believed that it would pass through a
region of country which could never give it any business
support. Now it is universally regarded, here and elsewhere,
as the road for Louisiana and Texas, in comparison with
wh.ch all the other projected railroads are unimportant.—
That it will be to Louisiana and Texas what the great Erie
Canal has been to the State of New York. It is satisfactorily ascertained that there are no natural obstacles to its construction,—that, on the contrary, it may be built, easier and
cheaper, mile for mile, than any other railroad made or projected in the United States,—that it will traverse a section
°t country, of already largely developed productive wealth :
